<target_code>
Here is the code of lfs_fs_pred:
```c
static int lfs_fs_pred(lfs_t *lfs,
        const lfs_block_t pair[2], lfs_mdir_t *pdir) {
    // iterate over all directory directory entries
    pdir->tail[0] = 0;
    pdir->tail[1] = 1;
    struct lfs_tortoise_t tortoise = {
        .pair = {LFS_BLOCK_NULL, LFS_BLOCK_NULL},
        .i = 1,
        .period = 1,
    };
    int err = LFS_ERR_OK;
    while (!lfs_pair_isnull(pdir->tail)) {
        err = lfs_tortoise_detectcycles(pdir, &tortoise);
        if (err < 0) {
            return LFS_ERR_CORRUPT;
        }

        if (lfs_pair_cmp(pdir->tail, pair) == 0) {
            return 0;
        }

        int err = lfs_dir_fetch(lfs, pdir, pdir->tail);
        if (err) {
            return err;
        }
    }

    return LFS_ERR_NOENT;
}
```

All other code in the provided snippets uses standard C constructs (function signature, array parameter, pointer dereference, while loop, return statements, macro cast ((lfs_block_t)-1), integer assignments, and ordinary declarations). There are no other obvious compiler-specific extensions in the code (no inline assembly, no __attribute__ or __declspec, no typeof, no statement-expressions, no GCC/Clang/MSVC-specific keywords or builtins).
